metadata.title: Right tree, right place, right time: A visual-functional design approach to select and place trees for optimal shade benefit to commuting pedestrians

Sustainable Cities and Society

Right tree, right place, right time: A visual-functional design approach to select and place trees for optimal shade benefit to commuting pedestrians
Nano Langenheima,⁎, Marcus Whiteb, Nigel Tapperc, Stephen J. Livesleyd, Diego Ramirez-Loveringa
a Art, Design and Architecture, Monash University, 900 Dandenong Rd, Caulfield East, VIC, 3145, Australia b School of Design, Swinburne University, Hawthorn Campus, John Street, Hawthorn, VIC, 3122, Australia c School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment, Monash University, Wellington Rd, Clayton, VIC, 3800, Australia d School of Ecosystem and Forest Science, Burnley Campus, Faculty of Science, The University of Melbourne, 500 Yarra Boulevard, Richmond, VIC, 3121, Australia
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Street tree shade Street design School journeys Active transport Performance-based design Ecosystem services
A B S T R A C T
Australia tops the world’s charts in occurrence of skin cancer and intensity of heat waves, while concurrently achieving high childhood obesity levels, due in part to low rates of physical activity. These issues converge in the challenge of protecting school children from heat and ultra-violet light exposure whilst simultaneously encouraging them to select active modes of transport for school journeys.
This paper describes a new performance-based tree-scape design approach for quantifying shaded walking routes using the pedestrian accessibility modelling tool “PedestrianCatch”, combined with visual-functional treescape modelling for both solar impact analysis and qualitative aesthetic outcomes of different street tree-scape designs. We test this design approach on a precinct surrounding a school as a case study.
The study results demonstrate the potential for targeted strategic street tree selection and planting in proximity to schools, providing the co-benefits of improved thermal comfort and reduced solar and ultra-violet exposure of children walking home from school. This performance-based design approach offers local government, public health and education departments with a way to mediate multiple and divergent concerns for climate amelioration, transport choices and population health by planting the right tree, positioned to provide shade in the right place at the right time.

sections.heading: 1.1. Visual and functional considerations
sections.text:
Urban tree-scape design decision making, has traditionally been undertaken by landscape architects, often in conjunction with community groups in public participatory forums (PPD), with a focus on qualitative visual impact (Arnold, 1980). In recent decades, the functional potential of street trees to improve many emerging urban environmental and social problems has caused a shift in the perception of the role of trees in cities (Bolund & Hunhammar, 1999; Freeman, Herriges, & Kling, 2014). This perceptual shift is reflected in the development of new terminology describing urban vegetation, for instance, as a form of ‘green infrastructure’ (Bélanger, 2009; Benedict & McMahon, 2002) and the development of quantitative approaches, adapted from financial modelling to calculate functional tree benefits; known as ecosystem service science (Costanza et al., 1998; Livesley,
McPherson, & Calfapietra, 2016). The traditional qualitative, visually focused design approach and the quantitative functional ecosystem services approach to tree decision-making share many objectives, such as providing shade for pedestrians or the increase in thermal comfort of urban areas, but their methods and focus differ. Traditional design approaches use methods which emphasise production of clear communication imagery while ecosystem service science emphasises the role of provisioning, supporting, regulating and cultural services of trees and their benefit to human or environmental health (Carpenter et al., 2009; Costanza et al., 1998). What is missing is a performancebased tree-scape design method, which blends these two approaches, and can be used to analyse both the visual, as well as the human and environmental performance (ecosystem services) of tree-scape decisions (Olander et al., 2017; Rosenthal et al., 2015; Vogt et al., 2017). Along with the targeted visual and ecosystem service benefits of any performance-based approach, there may also be additional ‘co-benefits’ or disservices (Pataki et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 1.2. Traditional tree-scape design can leave pedestrians exposed at critical footpath use-times
sections.text:
Customarily, trees have been planted in symmetrical rows on either side of a street, stemming from the popular influence of French formal design on urban compositional ideas during British colonial expansion in the 19th century (Dover & Massengale, 2013; Lawrence, 2006). While this symmetrical layout of trees has many aesthetic benefits (Arnold, 1980), depending on the orientation of the street, the time of day, the season, geographic location of the city, and the pedestrian peak-use time, this symmetrical street verge planting design can leave pedestrians exposed to solar radiation and vulnerable to heat (Norton et al., 2015).
A peak time of pedestrian footpath use is the mid-afternoon homeward journey undertaken by many school children, at approximately 15.30. School children who use active transport modes, such as walking and cycling for this journey, are more likely to reach recommended daily levels of physical activity, become adults with healthier lifestyle habits and are less likely to suffer from health problems such as cardio vascular disease and obesity (Faulkner, Buliung, Flora, & Fusco, 2009; Larouche, Saunders, Faulkner, Colley, & Tremblay, 2014). Encouraging walking and cycling to and from school is therefore clearly important, but several barriers are contributing to the steady decline of active modes for this journey (Larsen, Buliung, & Faulkner, 2015). These barriers include poor perceptions of aesthetics, child safety, and comfort of the street environment and the risks of exposure to harmful levels of air pollution, Ultra Violet (UV) radiation and heat (Bertazzon & Shahid, 2017; Dirks, Salmond, & Talbot, 2018; Huang, Lin, & Lien, 2015; Kim, Lee, & Jun-Hyun, 2018; Lee, Zhu, Yoon, & Varni, 2013; Sweeney & Von Hagen, 2016). Minimising these barriers is therefore a critical issue and one which can be in part, addressed through development of performance-based, spatially explicit design methods for strategic placement and selection of trees.

sections.heading: 1.3. Reducing pedestrian heat stress and UV exposure with street tree canopy
sections.text:
Tree canopy cover provides protection from both heat stress and UV exposure (Grant, Heisler, Gao, & Jenks, 2003; Green, Wallingford, & McBride, 2011). Increasing tree canopy coverage in streetscapes which lead to and from schools has been shown to encourage active transport mode selections for school journeys due to better perceptions of safety, aesthetic value and thermal comfort (Handy, Boarnet, Ewing, & Killingsworth, 2002; Parisi & Turnbull, 2014). However, for tree canopy cover to provide these benefits, adjustments to traditional tree placements and species selections are required that consider street orientation, surrounding built form, season and geographic location (Rantzoudi & Georgi, 2017; Sanusi, Johnstone, May, & Livesley, 2016).
While tree shade is not the only factor which reduces urban heat and UV exposure, it is often the most important contributor. Tree shade has been shown to lower surface temperatures by up to 20 °C and intercept significant amounts of UV radiation (Ali-Toudert & Mayer, 2007; Grant et al., 2003; Mayer, Holst, Dostal, Imbery, & Schindler, 2008; Na, Heisler, Nowak, & Grant, 2014; Thom, Coutts, Broadbent, & Tapper, 2016). Tree shade may only lead to a relatively small reduction in air temperature beneath the canopy, but the change in other climate factors under tree shade, such as relative humidity, wind speed, and overall radiation loads mean that perceived human thermal comfort is greatly improved (Sanusi, Johnstone, May & Livesley, 2017).
The importance of tree shade as a component of human thermal comfort can be quantified in several ways, though in general for a simple ecosystem service benefit calculation, it can be measured directly (using shoulder attached dosimeters) as comparative periods of time in or out of shade over total time spent outdoors (Boldemann et al., 2006; Pagels, 2017). It is more difficult to model the impact of shade on human activity, as agent-based models which include complex human
behaviours that react to changes in thermal conditions are required (Melnikov, Krzhizhanovskaya, & Sloot, 2017). A more common modelling approach for thermal comfort is to calculate the shade at one point in the day when the sun is at the highest point in the sky (Solar noon), and the tree canopy outline is most closely aligned with the shade cast below (Norton, Coutts, Livesley, & Williams, 2013; Sanusi et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 1.4. Visual, spatial and environmental constraints
sections.text: Street tree planting is not simple to re-configure as several complex interactive constraints need to be considered in decision making. If the primary objective of planting trees in streets was to provide pedestrian shade, and there were no constraints as to what tree species could be selected or their planting positions, then this objective could be achieved without trepidation. There are however several constraints that obstruct change to current tree selection, planting location and management practices. Some of these constraints are spatial, such as the need to accommodate existing services within street easements either above or below ground. Some constraints are environmental, such as changing diurnal and seasonal sun positions, suitable tree rooting volumes and challenging urban soil conditions (Dobbs, Kendal, & Nitschke, 2014). Some constraints are visual, such as historical or community visual and cultural preferences (Gobster, Nassauer, Daniel, & Gary, 2007; Lange & Hehl-Lange, 2011). These competing and interacting constraints affect tree-scape performance, and though they may be discussed during decision-making, are rarely recognised or visualised together in a way which portrays the complexity and possible compromise solutions that can be made. As such, some visual or environmental performance criteria or opportunities can be overlooked during tree-scape planning against more regulatory demands of traffic flow or infrastructure service provision (Batty, 2013; Grêt-Regamey, Celio, Klein, & Hayek, 2013; Rosenthal et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 1.5. Tree modelling and microclimate simulation
sections.text: Visual simulation of trees in digital modelling platforms is an area of research for many disciplines from the gaming industry, defence, hydrology catchment management to agroforestry (Prusinkiewicz & Lindenmayer, 1990). While the uses of digital tree models may differ, many are constructed from the recursive branching methods developed by Honda (1971). These visually and structurally realistic three-dimensional, polygon dense tree models, have been shown to have high accuracy for environmental simulation (Sadeghi & Mistrick, 2018) but have required considerable computing power. Similar can be said of microclimate performance simulation undertaken in the early stages of design projects. Early attempts to compute microclimatic performance of designs initially often took many hours to run, making them unfeasible for adoption in industry (He & Hoyano, 2009). However, recent advances in computer software and hardware have resulted in increased rendering speed and efficiency which now make it feasible to both import multiple digital polygon-dense trees into large 3-dimensional urban precinct simulation projects and calculate basic microclimatic impacts (Belok, Rabea, Hanafi, & Bastawissi, 2019; Gill, 2013; Jabi, 2016; White & Langenheim, 2018).

sections.heading: 1.6. The question this research aims to answer is
sections.text: Can tree-scape design be undertaken in a strategic and flexible way so that designers can quantify ecosystem service performance of trees for footpath shading of school children in pedestrian walking catchments, whilst still communicating traditional design performance objectives such as visual impact?

sections.heading: 2. Method
sections.text:
In this study, we develop a coupled, performance-based visualfunctional tree-scape design approach, which can output quantitative calculations of shade provision to active transport users while simultaneously providing traditional qualitative visual impact imagery used in public participatory decision-making arenas. To form the visualfunctional approach, we bring together two modelling methods. The first of these, the pedestrian accessibility analysis model, is a simple agentbased tool which can analyse walking catchments for specific destination nodes such as railway stations or, in this case, schools. Pedestrians (agents) navigate through the street network to calculate walking catchments based on time such as the commonly used 10min’ walk, considering physical obstructions such as freeways and waterways. In this case we use the experimental version of ‘PedestrianCatch’ developed in Rhinoceros 3D™ with the Grasshopper visual scripting plug-in version which, in addition to assessing accessibility, also samples the pixel intensity of a background image (White, Kimm, & Langenheim, 2017). The illustration below (Fig. 1), is a simple demonstration of the tool used to analyse the difference in solar exposure on a North-South street at mid-day (a), and in the afternoon (b), showing the significant impact the time of day can have on pedestrian shading.
The second model was developed for streetscape tree decision support. This model uses the functionality of gaming and animation industry software with a solar metric sun-system and advanced processing of polygon-dense 3-dimensional trees, to provide traditional design imagery for qualitative visual decision making support and shade quantification within urban streetscapes (White & Langenheim, 2018). From this model, shade maps of tree planting scenarios at children’s head height (1.2 m) are ‘rendered out’, using a texture baking technique which captures shadows of objects in isolation, on a surface (Möller, 1996).
The visual-functional approach is then tested on a case study site in a residential area surrounding two primary schools to the west of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. This homeward journey timeframe of 15.30, coincides with peak Summer season heat and UV levels) is principally above the threshold at which the World Health Organisation recommends application of sun protection or total sun avoidance for children (World Health Orgnisation, 2018).
The design approach uses a seven-step process:
3.1 The definition of the ten-minute walking catchment around the two schools using the pedestrian accessibility catchment calculator ‘PedestrianCatch’.
3.2 The street network of the catchment is then classified by orientation and width, and intersection models are created for each classification. 3.3 In the intersection models’ lines of trees are placed into the optimal position of the available placement options within the street casement to providing footpath shade at 15.30. 3.4 Depending on the street orientation and tree placement option, optimal tree form models are then selected and placed along the tree lines at spacing which maximises shade. 3.5 The tree form models are then ‘fitted’ to a preferred species list of trees, known to do well in the harsh soil and climatic conditions of the area. 3.6 The tree form models are then replaced with, polygon-dense, visually realistic recursive tree models of selected species from the preferred list. 3.7 The lines of tree models are then used to output a shade map using the texture baking technique at approximately children’s head height (1.2 m). The shade map is then taken into the pedestrian accessibility analysis model and pedestrian ‘agents’ sample these shade maps as they move along the street with a given exposure time of three minutes.
The approach was applied to an entire 3-dimensional site model of the walking catchment and three tree-scape planting scenarios were tested: 1) the existing tree-scape, 2) improved tree-scape to optimise shading conditions accepting the existing infrastructure constraints and 3) improved tree-scape with infrastructure constraints removed to fully optimise tree shading conditions. Finally, the differences between each shading scenario were quantified as number of households whose children could reach home with less than three minutes exposure time.
This work was undertaken on a Dell XPS 15 2016 9550 with a 6th Gen Intel Core i7-6700HQ processor, 16GB DDR4 memory, Nvidia GeForce 960M 2GB GDDR5 VRAM;
Final software versions are Autodesk™ 3 ds Max 2019™ update 1.1 with plugin Forest Pack version 6.1 and render engines Chaos Group™ V-Ray GPU for 3 ds Max version 3.6™. Tree models are a combination of user-created trees using the plugin Exlevel™ GrowFX™ version 1.9.9. 3 ds Max was selected as the platform for model production as it is freely available to researchers and has suitable capacity / for performance of the developed system and interoperability with the required plugins.

sections.heading: 3.1. Generate the walking catchment
sections.text: The ten-minute walking catchment of the school zone was calculated using the online tool www.PedestrianCatch.com. The main school gate was set as the single destination/start point, walking speed of pedestrians was set to 1.33m/s, and a 50m offset buffer isochronestype was chosen (Fig. 2A). The resulting catchment area was 1,276,256 m2 compared with the as-the-crow-flies circular catchment of 2,003,595m2 (0.637 pedestrian catchment ratio).

sections.heading: 3.2. Categorise the streets by width and orientation
sections.text: The polygon street casement data set of the surrounding area was sourced from Vicmap, the authoritative spatial data for the State of Victoria, Australia, and downloaded from the Victorian data portal website (Vicmap Property, 2017). The streets within the ped-shed were categorised into typologies (Fig. 2B) based on width and orientation as discussed by Rantzoudi and Georgi (2017). Most of the precinct conformed to a grid pattern on a 7° angle from the cardinal orientation, with either 15m or 20m wide streets apart from a major transport thoroughfare which bisected the precinct on an orientation of ESE 30° turning into ESE 27°. Streets narrower than 12m in width were excluded from tree planting consideration for practicality and limited tree planting options.

sections.heading: 3.3. Establishing tree placement options
sections.text:
Tree planting options are spatially limited due to building egress and ingress requirements and car lane changes and parking access. While unusual possibilities for tree placement have been trialled occasionally, such as in Leonard Circus, London (Jaluzot, James, & Pauli, 2014), experimental tree locations still require a great deal of driver behavioural change to work effectively (Kennedy, 2014). The objective for this study was to know what shading performance increase could be achieved using six possible planting locations (Fig. 3): A) within the private realm setbacks, B) at the property boundary, C) at the kerb edge, D) between car parking bays, E) within a road median (only
available in wider streets), F) beyond the bike path (only available where the bike path is located adjacent to the footpath).
Each of these locations has varying degrees of achievability. For instance; position A) privately owned front setbacks can be controversial as there are substantial difficulties associated with regulating vegetation occurring within private property (Parmehr, Amati, Taylor, & Livesley, 2016) and position F) is only achievable if bike paths are located adjacent the footpath. Each possible location was colour coded which allowed for immediate feedback as to whether the optimal tree alignment would require minimal or substantial changes to the existing streetscape infrastructure.

sections.heading: 3.4. Optimise tree placement for pedestrian shading
sections.text:
Each street orientation-width classification was then developed into a detailed single intersection cross-road model using Autodesk’s 3 dsMax™. Using these intersection models rather than single street sections allowed perpendicular street orientation-width classifications to be tested concurrently. In the intersection studies, simple tree geometry models were placed in linear arrays and colour coded according to where they could best provide shading to the footpaths and bike paths at the peak time (15.30) (Fig. 3).
3.5. Optimise tree geometry to achieve greatest shading benefit
To assess the impact of tree form and size on shade provision performance seven basic tree forms were modelled (Fig. 4A). The output visualisation showed that east-west oriented streets required wider canopy trees for shading pedestrians, while in north-south oriented streets taller tree forms, particularly if they were closely spaced, achieved greater pedestrian shade during the target time period (Fig. 4). The requirement to consider tree canopy form was particularly evident on north-south oriented streets where centrally placed trees would only provide footpath shading benefit if the canopy was vase shaped (Fig. 4B). The tree geometry model, height, width and spacings between, were adjusted until optimal shading at 15.30 could be achieved. All adjustments to heights and widths of the tree geometry models are presented in Table 1.

sections.heading: 3.6. Select tree species as tree form models
sections.text: Once locations, spacing and overall tree form, height and canopy width were established it was then possible to select the best fitting tree species from the council list of preferred tree species, known to be well suited to the local soil and climatic conditions and require minimal ongoing maintenance (Table 1 and Fig. 4C, E). This process revealed that certain tree growth forms and dimensions were not well represented in preferred species lists while other growth habits were overrepresented. For example, on direct east-west oriented streets the change in the position of the sun over the course of the summer season would require a very wide-canopy tree if it was to provide shade for footpaths over the entire Summer season. No tree species on the council preferred list fit the canopy width dimension required for that function unless substantial formative pruning was undertaken. In contrast, on north-south oriented streets tree canopy height was more important than the canopy width for achieving optimal shade. Several tree species on the preferred council list provided the desired tree form and dimension for that orientation. Streets closer to north-south orientations gained most shading benefit from trees planted in the front set back or private properties. These are Positions A and B (Fig. 3A and B) colour coded in red and dark blue, respectively. It may be challenging or controversial to place trees in these locations in many cities, as it is difficult to control private property planting (Parmehr et al., 2016). Similarly, it may not be feasible to stipulate a single tree species that residents must plant in their front yards. As such, the tree form models could be used to generate performance-based indicators with dimension requirements, or private residence owners could choose from a selection of dimensionally suitable species.

sections.heading: 3.7. Fit three-dimensional recursive tree models to selected tree species
sections.text: Once the most suitable tree species has been selected a 3-dimensional, visually accurate, recursive, polygon-dense model was either selected from a commercially available library (Xfrog ™) or generated using the commercially available plugin Exlevel™. The recursive polygon-dense models were then used to supplant the tree-geometry models (Fig. 4C). In the case of the positioning of trees in A) the front setback, a selection of species which met the size and form criteria were generated and applied to the model as a randomized layout.

sections.heading: 4. Testing the visual-functional design approach on a precinct case-study
sections.text: With the tree planting strategies for each individual street category selected, a 3-dimensional, digital model of the walking catchment was constructed in 3 ds Max™ from spatial data sets available to researchers through the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network (AURIN). Street casements were obtained from (Vicmap Property, 2017), building footprints from (Melbourne Water Corporation, 2018) and land parcel maps from (PSMA Australia Limited, 2016). A spatial data layer of existing tree species and locations was provided by the City of Maribyrnong. The walking catchment model was tested for built form footpath shading at 15.30. Building shadows did not impact upon the study area footpaths at this time of day as the morphology consisted of one and two storey buildings set-back from the road.

sections.heading: 4.1. Testing three tree-planting design scenarios
sections.text:
In applying the design approach to an entire walking catchment, we
wanted to compare the child pedestrian head height shade to school children on their homeward journey from school under three scenarios based around three questions:
1) What amount of shading was being provided by the existing urban forest? 2) What level of shading could be achieved with new tree plantings
without disruption to current infrastructure? and 3) What level of shading could be achieved if strategic changes to in-
frastructure could be made?
For scenario 1): ‘Existing shading’, the existing GIS tree locations provided by the council were used to inform the location and size of recursive visual polygon-dense tree models. For scenario 2): ‘Improved
shading’, additional trees were placed in locations that did not disrupt existing infrastructure, such as at the curb edge (Fig. 3C), between parking bays (Fig. 3D) and in any available central median strips (Fig. 3E). For the added trees, model form, height, width and spacing were adjusted to maximize shading within these three possible planting locations.
For scenario 3): ‘Optimal shading’ additional trees were placed in all six possible tree planting positions under the assumption that infrastructure service constraints were removed in a whole of precinct “upgrade” (Fig. 5a).

sections.heading: 4.2. Shade map generation
sections.text: Shade-maps for each scenario were then generated using the shadow-baking technique described above. The baking process is undertaken with the sun position set to 15.30 and the ‘receiving plane’ is set to 1.2 m height. This results in a child’s head height, geo-referenced shade map. (Fig. 5B) shows a detailed example of the texture baked head height shadow map on the right.

sections.heading: 4.3. Analyze the shade-maps
sections.text: Each shade-map was then georeferenced into the prototype version of the PedestrianCatch tool which, in addition to calculating the walking catchment, can also analyse the pixel intensity value of a raster-based shade-map to identify where a pedestrian is walking in shade or is unshaded (White et al., 2017). A threshold can be set in this tool for a maximum sun exposure time. Upon reaching that threshold the pedestrian agent stops. In this scenario testing a threshold of cumulative three minutes exposure to full sun was set (Fig. 6A, B, C).

sections.heading: 4.4. Compare the shade map analysis
sections.text:
The sunlight exposure-limited pedestrian catchments were then compared through a dwelling count process. The perimeter limit of
each shaded catchment was overlaid with the building footprint outline data and a simple ‘dwellings reached’ count was used to quantify the difference between the shade provision of each scenario (Fig. 6A, B, C).
Under the Scenario 1: ‘existing shading’ conditions 320 dwellings could be reached from the school gate with no more than three minutes direct exposure. In Scenario 02: ‘improved shade’, where shading was maximised within the confines of the existing hard infrastructure layout, the number of dwellings which could be reached before agents terminated under a three-minute exposure time more than doubled, with 794 dwellings. While Scenario 03: ‘optimal shading’, where hard infrastructure was adjusted, showed a moderate performance improvement on scenario 02) at 935 dwellings (Fig. 6F).

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text:
Environmental and spatially explicit visualisation approaches are recognised for having powerful possibilities to improve design outcomes, when incorporated into PPD decision making (Bishop & Lange, 2005; Gill, 2013; Grêt-Regamey et al., 2013; Pettit et al., 2008; Schroth, Hayek, Lange, Sheppard, & Schmid, 2011). While this study builds on these approaches it has a key difference. In this study changes in environmental conditions brought about by different decisions are calculated directly from the visualisation model rather than a final visualisation being output from a coupled database.
While many studies have been undertaken, with the aim of using spatially explicit visualisation to communicate the human thermal comfort outcomes of urban tree-scape decisions, we found most were focused on the production of comfort or heat maps, using abstracted voxel-based tree morphology (Lindberg & Grimmond, 2011; Rosheidat, Hoffman, & Bryan, 2008). The abstract nature of these tree visualisations make them unsuitable for assessment of visual impact of tree choices on the streetscape, which can be the paramount performance priority in PPD. Similarly, the numeric outputs of ecosystem service calculation for thermal comfort can lack relevance for stakeholders or can be too abstract, for successful use in PPD (Laurans & Mermet, 2014;
Liu & Opdam, 2014; Olander et al., 2017; Rosenthal et al., 2015; Vogt et al., 2017). The above studies identify that there is extensive potential for street trees to benefit human and environmental health, but that communicating these benefits to allow them equal consideration with traditional visual tree selection criteria during decision making is difficult. Development of performance-based design approaches which intersect traditional visualisation with ecosystem service calculation and spatially explicit decision analysis are therefore critical (Laurans & Mermet, 2014).
Our study focused on the possibilities which arise with the adoption of a spatially explicit visualisation approach for tree-scape decision making for the school homeward journey undertaken by children. Common to studies which tackle the barriers to using active modes of transport for this crucial journey are outcomes which highlight the need for spatially explicit performance-based public health policies and decision making approaches regarding streetscapes (Bertazzon & Shahid, 2017; Grêt-Regamey, Sirén, Brunner, & Weibel, 2017; Handy et al., 2002; Larsen et al., 2009). Multiple studies show that the needs of child pedestrians are unique, and that mode choice for this journey is crucial to adult health outcomes (Larouche et al., 2014; Larsen et al., 2009). Children are more vulnerable to heat exposure due to their closer proximity to heat storing ground surfaces (Kim et al., 2018). Children’s skin is thinner than adult skin and therefore more sensitive to exposure to UV (Jones & Guy, 2017; Holman, Kapelos, Shoemaker, & Watson, 2018). In addition, children, are particularly vulnerable to air pollution
as their respiratory systems are still developing (Garcia, Cerdeira, Coelho, Kumar, & da Graça Carvalho, 2014; Sunyer et al., 2015), and have higher pedestrian risk as they have greater vulnerability to road traffic dangers (Ewing & Dumbaugh, 2009; Naderi, Maghelal, & Kweon, 2008) with road traffic injury being the leading cause of child injury, disability and death globally (Howard, 2010). Street trees can play a role in improving all of these barriers to active transport, but only if considered spatially and planted on streets with respect to these criteria.
Our study highlights the possibility for extensive impact on the comfort and UV exposure levels of children walking home, with adoption of this performance-based approach to tree scape decisionmaking. Shade provision could potentially be doubled for that journey through simple strategic planting locations and species selection. While the expectation of the authors was that scenario 03) would represent a more dramatic improvement than scenario 02, a number of site-specific factors impact the agent expiry, such as the water body which has no crossing point and the large 60-meter-wide road to the west. The short exposure limit was also a factor in that the three-minute exposure threshold setting is quickly taken up at road intersections where traffic visibility requirements make shading difficult to achieve. While the greatest increase in total households able to reach their destination within the three-minute exposure time was greatest in scenario two, in scenario 3 both sides of the footpath were shaded, something which could not be quantified using the simple catchment perimeter overlay
dwelling count method. For people walking young children to school this might represent a reduced need for road crossings, and thereby an increase in the perception of safety of active transport mode selections.

sections.heading: 5.1. Limitations and further study
sections.text:
The developed design approach works with the constraints of slight variations in street geometry and street configuration. However, there are several other site-specific variables such as allotment size, on-site driveway provision and services which could be included in the model in the future. For example, the spatially explicit location and associated clearances of high-voltage overhead power lines could be incorporated into the method to inform maximum tree height decisions under this service infrastructure. Incorporation of this data could reduce or eliminate the substantial costs and poor visual implications associated with annual tree pruning around these services (Aurecon, 2016; Jaluzot, James, & Pauli, 2012).
In this case-study, the scope was limited to looking at the objective of maximizing shade provision for pedestrians walking home from school at that particular time of day. We did not examine the visual impact of the different tree-scape options beyond ensuring that the visual output of the model would be suitable to do such, and this could inform a future, larger scope study.
In addition, quantifying the expected direct UV exposure times for children living outside the existing shaded walking catchment, and potential health benefits after implementation of the alternative treescape design scenarios was beyond the scope of this study.
Though this study focused on school-age children, the approach could also be used to improve adult commuter’s shade protection whilst walking or cycling to public transport nodes, or the movement of older adults from recognized age-in-place housing and aged-care facilities to local community centers or shops, to encourage continued activity and to reduce exposure to high solar radiation on summer days.
The study site was a typical low-density, low-diversity residential land-use and a reasonably regular street pattern which lent itself to categorization and therefore common streetscape treatments. More complex scenarios, with multiple objectives or places with irregular street patterning, orientation changes or curves, it might be more difficult to obtain generalizable tree layouts or single tree positionings. In these scenarios, our modelling approach would need to be expanded to include automation of analysis of the larger sets of variables.
While there was sometimes more than one species from the council tree list which ‘fit’ the form and size criteria output of the model, in other situations, there were few or no species which fitted the criteria. For the local authority, this means a need to investigate expansion of their preferred tree list, either through more trial and error of targeted species with desirable dimensions, or alternatively, developing methods for targeted improvement of soil and water resource quantity and quality in strategic locations. This undertaking would have additional benefits for the tree-scapes of the precinct, either increasing the tree species diversity of the area and or increasing the health and vigor of existing tree plantings.
The scope of this study was limited to precinct scale, though due to the efficiency of the modelling approach, there is potential to apply it at a much larger scale such as multiple suburbs. In the future, as computer hardware improves and software efficiency increases, it is not unrealistic to expect the approach could be applied to whole metropolitan areas. The main barriers to city-wide scale of implementation would come down to limited municipal resources: time, money and expertise (Daniel, 2017). The approach requires cross-disciplinary input from planers working closely with urban designers and landscape architects with sufficient spatial design and technical skills. Though our system is relatively rapid to implement, this performance-based visual-functional approach is both site condition and socio-politically specific. At this stage considerable resource commitment would be required to allow for larger scaled consultation or inclusion of multiple, more complex
combinations of land uses, or to go beyond precinct scale. We therefore recommend our approach be used for medium to large scale precinct application but suggest traditional canopy cover metrics are more suitable for metropolitan scale analysis at this time.
This study demonstrates the shade ecosystem service benefit of strategically increasing treescape trees but does not quantify potential negative impacts, such as increased demand for infrastructure costs for example; tree-pits, paving maintenance and pruning, watering trees during droughts, and potential increased risks associated with falling tree branches.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: A performance-based, flexible, digital design approach was described which can be used to model the multitude of spatial, environmental and visual objectives, constraints and methods involved in treescape decisions, and to make these objectives visible and quantifiable. To our knowledge, this is the first study that combines pedestrian access modelling, tree-scape shade modelling and shade optimization whilst simultaneously allowing for high-quality and realistic visual impact assessment. The use of this design approach would give tree managers and tree-scape designers agency in the argument for better positioning, spacing, species selection and conditions of trees in streets. In this study, the modelling design approach was used to quantify the shade to child pedestrians on the way home from school ecosystem service benefit of trees as well as communicate traditional design objectives such as visual impact. The results of the study demonstrate that it is possible to make street trees more effective at accommodating active pedestrian travel if they are located based on a consideration of street orientation and width, solar geometry, and physical characteristics of proposed tree species in combination with the peak pedestrian use-time based on land-use. This tree-led urban design approach offers local government ways to mediate multiple and divergent concerns for climate amelioration, transport choices and population health by planting the right tree in the right place to cast shade at the right time.

metadata.abstractText: Australia tops the world’s charts in occurrence of skin cancer and intensity of heat waves, while concurrently achieving high childhood obesity levels, due in part to low rates of physical activity. These issues converge in the challenge of protecting school children from heat and ultra-violet light exposure whilst simultaneously encouraging them to select active modes of transport for school journeys. This paper describes a new performance-based tree-scape design approach for quantifying shaded walking routes using the pedestrian accessibility modelling tool “PedestrianCatch”, combined with visual-functional treescape modelling for both solar impact analysis and qualitative aesthetic outcomes of different street tree-scape designs. We test this design approach on a precinct surrounding a school as a case study. The study results demonstrate the potential for targeted strategic street tree selection and planting in proximity to schools, providing the co-benefits of improved thermal comfort and reduced solar and ultra-violet exposure of children walking home from school. This performance-based design approach offers local government, public health and education departments with a way to mediate multiple and divergent concerns for climate amelioration, transport choices and population health by planting the right tree, positioned to provide shade in the right place at the right time.
